bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Pedro Nogueira, September 9, 1947

div1.p: Kean informs Nogueira that there were no deaths through human experimentation at Camp Lazear. However, Andrus caused Reed great anxiety because he had a severe case of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Pedro Nogueira, September 9, 1947
div1.opener:
Copy.
2804 N Street N. W.
Washington 7, D. C.
Air mail.
9 Sept. '47-
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Maoti 219 Marianao Cuba
Dear Dr Nogueira
div1.p:
It gives me pleasure to receive today
your letter of Sept. 7th with regard to the experimental
cases of yellow fever at Camp Lazear in 1900-1901.
I am glad to say that no death occurred among
the patients who submitted to these experiments.
One of them Private Andrus, American Soldier, caused
Major Walter Reed much anxiety, as his case was severe
and recovery slow, having been compliccated by the
development of a large carbuncle. It was a blood infection case*
Dr. Espin may have confused these cases with another
series of experimental cases of yellow fever con-
ducted at Las Animas Hospital in Havana at
a later date, under the direction of Major later Maj. Gen. W. C. Gorgas
M.C. US Army and Dr. Carlos Finlay, Chairman of the Yellow
Fever Commission. These cases were instituted because
Major Gorgas believed as he told me, that the Camp Lazear cases hav-
ing caused no mortality indicated that a milder
type of disease was produced than was the case with
yellow fever acquired in a natural way. These experi-
ments were brought to a sudden end when three
deaths occurred in seven cases this was in August 1901.
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely Jefferson R Kean Brig. Gen. Retd.
* Not from a mosquito but from blood taken from Private Forbes a mosquito infected case.
